DOC.HEAD: Late Payments On Bank Loans At Decade High
DOC.TEXT: The number of consumers 30 days or more behind in their payments on bank loans rose sharply during the July-September period to the highest level of the decade, a banking group reported. According to a survey by the American Bankers Association, 2.88 percent of closed-end installment loans were delinquent in September, compared with 2.30 percent in June and 2.42 percent in September 1988. The steep rise followed two quarter-to-quarter declines. Virginia Stafford, a spokeswoman for the bankers' group, said Thursday that the next-highest end-of-quarter total was 2.74 percent, reached in the second quarter of 1980 when the country was in recession. Robert Dugger, the association's chief economist, said an increase was expected because of the slowing economy. However, he called the current rate ``still in the manageable range.'' Also, banks are making fewer new consumer loans. That means as borrowers pay off old loans, the proportion in delinquency rises. The delinquency rate is based on a nationwide survey of 800 banks. It includes seven different types of closed-end consumer loans: personal, two types of auto loans, mobile home, recreational vehicle, property improvement and home equity.
